$TSM ISN‚ÄôT JUST PART OF THE AI BOOM -- IT IS THE AI BOOM

Hard to overstate how critical this company has become to AI -- It‚Äôs the company the entire industry is built on.

TSMC just delivered 39% YoY revenue growth and a 40% surge in the first half -- a clear signal that global compute demand isn‚Äôt just ramping, it‚Äôs consolidating into fewer, more essential players.

Every major name in AI -- $NVDA, $AAPL, $AMD, $QCOM -- relies on TSMC to turn designs into production. The whole ecosystem flows through their fabs.

Sure, there are questions around CapEx, margin drag from overseas expansion, and smartphone seasonality. But that‚Äôs the trade-off when you're building the physical foundation of the AI economy.

That‚Äôs why TSMC is the top stock in our @FuturumEquities AI Fifteen list -- not because it‚Äôs loud, but because it‚Äôs indispensable.

Getting this question more and more -- is the small-cap portfolio too spread out with 23 positions?

So here‚Äôs how I‚Äôm thinking about it:

‚Ä¢ If I was running a large-cap portfolio? Yeah, 23 would probably be overkill. But in small-caps, it‚Äôs a different game. You‚Äôre not looking for every name to double -- you‚Äôre looking for a few to 5‚Äì10x. And to find those, you need surface area. You need exposure. Because let‚Äôs be real -- some of these will flame out, and that‚Äôs fine.

‚Ä¢ This is the part of the market where optionality matters more than concentration. I‚Äôd rather own 20+ names I‚Äôve spent real time on and give myself a shot at catching the next $IONQ or $RKLB -- instead of swinging for the fences with 3‚Äì5 names and blowing up if one goes south.

‚Ä¢ I‚Äôm not throwing darts. I size based on conviction, catalysts, timelines -- some are bigger, some are just spec moonshots. But every position earns its keep. And in this space, I‚Äôd argue this is actually risk management, not over-diversification.

‚Ä¢ Could I be wrong on some? Of course. But I‚Äôd rather be wrong small on a few and right big on the ones that matter -- that‚Äôs the whole point of this approach. It‚Äôs not about being perfect, it‚Äôs about surviving long enough to get paid when you‚Äôre right.

10 M&A DEALS THAT WOULD JUST MAKE SENSE IN 2025

1. $UBER buys $RIVN -- locks in EV supply & takes control of its autonomy roadmap instead of waiting on $TSLA or OEM scraps.

2. $MSFT buys $OKTA -- folds identity leadership into Azure & makes Active Directory the default login layer for enterprise cloud.

3. $ORCL buys $AI -- slaps real gen AI onto Oracle‚Äôs ERP stack & sells AI-native apps to legacy enterprise. 

4. $DDOG buys $FSLY -- locks in real-time edge control to future-proof observability as AI-native systems begin to bypass traditional monitoring stacks.

5. $AMZN buys $TWLO -- brings cloud comms in-house & gives AWS control over the messaging rails developers already use.

6. $GOOGL buys $GTLB -- expands GCP's vertical AI stack by bringing GitLab‚Äôs platform in-house, giving GCP deeper control over the full AI development lifecycle -- from code to production.

7. Databricks buys $CFLT -- completes the modern data stack by merging real-time streaming with lakehouse AI workflows.

8. $CRM buys $BRZE -- expands Salesforce‚Äôs data-driven marketing with Braze‚Äôs event-based engagement engine & mobile-first personalization stack.

9. $AAPL buys Perplexity -- drops Perplexity‚Äôs RAG engine into Safari, Spotlight, and Siri & finally shows up to the AI search war.

10. $CSCO buys $S -- strengthens Cisco‚Äôs AI security portfolio with SentinelOne‚Äôs autonomous threat detection & XDR capabilities.

üá∫üá∏ VIDEO GAME ACTORS JUST SLAPPED AI WITH A BIG FAT "NOPE"

After nearly a year on strike, voice and mocap actors just signed a deal that puts AI in its place.

Studios now need permission to clone voices or faces, and actors can yank that consent if things go sideways.

The deal also brings on-set medics for intense motion capture scenes and a sweet 15% pay bump right out of the gate.

EA, Activision, Disney, and more all had to sign on. 

Game over, AI.

Source: Reuters

Follow-up

The post above is correct; the lowest sovereign yields are the countries with the biggest problems.

So, yes, saying we should have the lowest yields is tantamount to saying our economy is the biggest mess.

I will attempt to interpret Trump and explain why his thinking is incorrect.

Trump's statement below suggests that the MAJOR factor driving rates is credit quality. Since he believes the US has the best credit quality ("companies pouring in", "the hottest country"), he concludes that we should have the lowest interest rates.

This is how a real estate developer from Queens thinks about yields: the best properties should have the lowest yields.

While true for private assets, such as Class A Manhattan office towers, this is not the case for developed-world sovereign yields. Credit quality is a VERY MINOR driver of their yields.

Nominal growth, inflation expectations, and anticipated supply drive the level of sovereign yields. 

All of Trump‚Äôs ‚Äúcredit‚Äù statements are arguments for high nominal growth and heightened inflation expectations. Add the increased supply, thanks to the BBB, and he is really making a compelling case for HIGHER Treasury yields.

$FCEL SIGNS MOU WITH INUVERSE FOR KOREA DATA CENTER POWER

FuelCell Energy signed a non-binding MOU with Inuverse to explore deploying up to 100 MW of fuel cell power at Inuverse‚Äôs upcoming AI Daegu Data Center in Korea. Deployment would begin in phases starting 2027. FuelCell‚Äôs systems will also provide thermal energy for absorption chilling to cool the facility. FCEL already operates Korea‚Äôs largest fuel cell park at 58 MW and aims to scale modularly with data center growth. Execs said the project will help meet surging AI processing demand while supporting renewable energy goals.

$SPY

You will all look to my account when the reverse carry trade returns.

And I won‚Äôt say a word.

Growing a business is very painful.

Not growing a business is very painful.

The cowards who attack others who take risks will ultimately suffer far more.

I have been more quiet on X for a reason.

You will find out why soon enough.

I will not relent.

Is housing broken?

In LA, the median household income is just over $91K.

At the same time, the median listing price is just under $1.2M, equating to a monthly expense of nearly $8,000, or 104.5% of the median household income.

Tesla's new car sales in Europe were down nearly 28% year on year in May as the company continues to battle competition from Chinese EV auto manufacturers.

If Chinese EVs were directly available in the US, would you purchase one?

The recent missile exchange between Iran and Israel/US didn't move oil prices as much as some might have expected.

Does this mean Middle Eastern politics is no longer a significant factor in global energy prices?

The Fed revealed plans to rescind a capital rule that big banks say limits their ability to hold more Treasuries in order to perform an intermediary role in the market.

The enhanced supplementary leverage ratio measure restricts the quantity and quality of capital banks should maintain on their balance sheets.

This is my first cousin's new book. Please purchase it. He's is one of the most knowledgeable authorities in the world on the subject. He was literally born off the grid! I know, I was there in a  living room in a house when he was born.
Living Off-Grid, REALLY a.co/d/2vkUV42

The market doesn't lie. It speaks in price action. The problem is, depending on when and where you are in the market, the lauagauge can change. Context is everything. Nothing can be trusted in a vacuum or in perpetuity. Don't be fooled. Even timeless tactics require timing.

I've been closely observing big breakout stocks like CHEF as "canary in the coal mine" indicators, looking for clues to determine if the market's character was shifting toward a more favorable environment for low risk breakout trading. The key words are LOW RISK. Unfortunately, yesterday provided a definitive answer‚Äîthough not the one we hoped for.

If you are a breakout trader using tight stops - even though the indexes have ripped higher - you have likely experienced a low batting average. 

The frequent occurrence of squats and outright failures continues to dominate as a theme around breakout levels, clearly signaling that conditions remain challenging and volatile around key risk levels.

These failed breakouts reveal persistent overhead supply and insufficient follow-through from institutional buyers, underscoring a risk off market with regard to broad-based participation. Hence, the continued gravitation to "old guard" names.

Like you, I remain an active participant and careful observer, adjusting day by day and ensuring risk management remains my top priority. As far as breakout stocks are concerned, this is NOT yet an Easy Dollar environment. For the most part, we are still fighting for pennies. 

For those who have been willing to allow for a bit more volatility, you are likely experiencing better results. If so, congrats; keep doing what is working for you. 

Let me know in the comments if you agree with this assessment and what you are experiencing during this V recovery..

"August 1993 ‚Äì The Moment the Market Met Minervini"

He was just 28.

No hedge fund.
No fancy suits.
Just a young man with a relentless hunger to decode the market.

That summer, while most were running from gold,
Mark Minervini was running toward it.

The headlines were grim.
Sentiment was cold.
But Mark?
He saw something the world didn‚Äôt.

A bottom forming.
A moment of truth.

He didn‚Äôt just talk about it.
He acted‚Äîloading up on gold stocks with unwavering conviction.

In a matter of months, they doubled.

The media finally came calling.
‚ÄúWho‚Äôs this guy who called the bottom?‚Äù
A feature story was printed.
A photo was taken.

@markminervini stood there‚Äî
A full head of hair, but even fuller belief in his process.

He wasn‚Äôt trading for clout.
He was trading because it was in his blood.

Because the market doesn‚Äôt reward opinions‚Äî
It rewards preparation, discipline, and courage under fire.

That moment in 1993 wasn‚Äôt just about a winning trade.

It was a declaration:
That you don‚Äôt need to be born on Wall Street to beat Wall Street.

You just need the will to suffer, the strength to study,
and the guts to pull the trigger when no one else will.
